Explanation:
An identifier that groups admission discharge records into a single episode of care, 
where an episode of care refers to all contiguous inpatient hospitalizations in general 
and psychiatric hospitals and all day surgery visits regardless of diagnoses, and where 
contiguous means discharge and admission occurs within 12 hours.

For Cerner only, functional independence measure (FIM) efficiency is calculated by 
dividing the change between the admission functional independence measure (FIM) 
total score and the discharge functional independence measure (FIM) total score by 
the elapsed time, in days, between the patient's admission and discharge dates.

After the admit_dt_tm, the first nursing unit entered that is not a 'Non-Funded - 
Holding Unit' or 'Non-Funded - Non-Holding Unit' that the patient enters. If no 
nursing unit matches that criteria, the first nursing unit entered that is a 'Non-Funded 
- Holding Unit'. If no nursing unit matches that criteria, the first nursing unit entered 
that is a 'Non-Funded - Non-Holding Unit'. If no nursing unit matches that criteria, the 
nursing unit at admit.

Identifies the case as Typical, Atypical, Long Stay or Atypical Long Stay.   
Typical Case include both factor and non-factor cases without the presence of unusual 
circumstances that would otherwise define the case as atypical and an observed total 
length of stay less than or equal to the trim point.   
Atypical Case is identified as representing unusual or exceptional circumstances occurred 
during the patient care episode; such as Death; Transfer to and/or from other acute care 
institutions; or Sign out. 
Long Stay Case is where the total length of stay greater than the trim point.   
A typical Long Stay is where the total length of stay greater than the trim point and one or 
more of the following circumstances occurred during the care episode: such as Death; 
Transfer to and/or from other acute care institutions; or Sign out. 
Usage Tip: Use for Acute Care Cases Only

The point after which the total Length of Stay is determined to be unusually long.   The final 
factor-adjusted trim point values are used with atypical status to define atypical code, 
specifically to identify long-stay cases. Cases with a total length of  stay greater than the 
computed trim point are considered long-stay cases. All trim point values are CMG, age 
category and factor-specific. Trim points have a forced minimum value of 3 days and a 
maximum value of 200 days.

Identifies the use of control interventions to restrain a patient during the first 3 days of 
their inpatient stay. Control interventions are generally used with the intention 
of protecting individuals from self-harm or preventing harm to another person. The 
definition of a restraint is any manual method, or physical or mechanic device, material or 
equipment attached 
or adjacent to the person’s body that the person cannot remove easily and that restricts 
the person’s freedom of movement or normal access to his or her body. It is the effect the 
device has on the person that classifies it as a restraint, not the name or label given to the 
device, nor the purpose or intent of the device. Chemical restraints are excluded from data 
collection. Record all of the following devices that were used during the first 3 days of 
patient stay. 
Usage Tip: This field may have up to 4 entries.  FY 2018-2019 New CIHI Field

of protecting individuals from self-harm or preventing harm to another person. The 
definition of a restraint is any manual method, or physical or mechanic device, material or 
equipment attached 
or adjacent to the person’s body that the person cannot remove easily and that restricts 
the person’s freedom of movement or normal access to his or her body. It is the effect the 
device has on the person that classifies it as a restraint, not the name or label given to the 
device, nor the purpose or intent of the device. Chemical restraints are excluded from data 
collection. Record all of the following devices that were used during the first 3 days of 
patient stay. 
Usage Tip: This field may have up to 4 entries.  FY 2018-2019 New CIHI Field

when MedRec must be completed. They include Admission, Transfer and Discharge. PHC 
Coding is currently collecting data for PHC MedRec on Admission to acute care. MedRec on 
Transfer, which is organizationally required for all inpatients post operatively and all 
patient transfer out of critical care (ICU, CCU, OR/PAR/SPH-HAU, MSJ-MHAU), was 
implemented across PHC acute care in January 2015.  
Legacy Field Name: MedRec_Transfer07Desc 
Usage Tip: PHC specific field 
This field may have up to 10 entries. 
Definition Source: Health Information Management Coding and Informatics services

Identifies if a CT scan or MRI scan was performed at the reporting acute care facility within 
the first 24 hours of arrival at the first facility OR a CT scan or MRI scan was performed 
within the first 24 hours of arrival at another acute care facility or ambulatory care facility 
prior to being directly transferred from that facility to the reporting acute care facility. 
Usage Tip: FY 2017-2018 New CIHI Field  
Definition Source: Stroke Project 340 SOPv10 18-21

In cases where the event is not witnessed or is so severe that the patient is unable to speak 
or self-report (patient alone or the event occurred during sleep), the date of onset is 
assumed to be the day the patient was last known to be well by a reliable witness. If the 
symptoms appeared but then stopped for more than 24 hours before the next symptoms 
appeared, treat the newer symptoms as the symptom onset date. If multiple episodes of 
symptoms appearing and resolving all happened within close proximity, the date recorded 
should be when the first symptoms appeared and were documented, even if they were 
intermittent. Subsequent symptoms may be attributed as progression of the “applicable 
condition” from the initial appearance of symptoms of the initial event. 
Legacy Field Name:  
Usage Tip: FY 2017-2018 New CIHI Field  
Definition Source: Stroke Project 340 SOPv10 18-22

In cases where the event is not witnessed or is so severe that the patient is unable to speak 
or self-report (patient alone or the event occurred during sleep), the time of onset is 
assumed to be the time the patient was last known to be well by a reliable witness. If the 
symptoms appeared but then stopped for more than 24 hours before the next symptoms 
appeared, treat the newer symptoms as the symptom onset time. If multiple episodes of

symptoms appearing and resolving all happened within close proximity, the time recorded 
should be when the first symptoms appeared and were documented, even if they were 
intermittent. Subsequent symptoms may be attributed as progression of the “applicable 
condition” from the initial appearance of symptoms of the initial event. 
Legacy Field Name: StrokeSymptomOnsetTime

more occurrences in the calculation.
